newsitem.title: USA: SEC names new enforcement chief in San Francisco.
newsitem.headline: SEC names new enforcement chief in San Francisco.

text.p: The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Wednesday it named a partner at a prominent law firm as head of enforcement in its San Francisco district office.

The SEC said in a statement that Helane Morrison, a partner at the San Francisco law firm of Howard, Rice, Nemerovski, Canady, Falk & Rabkin, replaces Robert Singletary, who left the enforcement chief's post in June.
While head of enforcement, Singletary led his office in an aggressive and controversial effort to investigate municipalities and municipal finance professionals.

David Bayless, the district administrator of the San Francisco district office, said the addition of Morrison "puts potential violators of the federal securities laws on notice that the SEC will continue to be vigilant and aggressive in its protection of investors."
Morrison graduated from Boalt Hall law school of the University of California at Berkeley in 1984, where she was editor-in-chief of the Law Review.

Upon graduation, she became a judicial law clerk to the Honorable Richard Posner of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. She then served as a judicial law clerk to Justice Harry Blackmun on the U.S. Supreme Court.

In 1986, she joined the law firm of Howard, Rice, where she became a partner in 1991. Morrison's litigation practice has specialized in federal securities laws, with experience in both SEC investigations and private litigation.
